title: AB 1228
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to encourage higher education institutions to provide information to foster care agencies about admissions requirements and financial aid. They also urge the Regents of the University of California and the Trustees of the California State University to consider using admissions-by-exemption to help homeless and foster youth transition into four-year public institutions. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is requested to prioritize housing for current and former homeless youth and foster youth in student housing facilities, especially during school breaks or year-round occupancy. The California Community Colleges are requested to prioritize housing for current and former homeless youth and foster youth in student housing facilities, giving first priority to them for year-round occupancy and during academic breaks at no extra cost. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is asked to create a plan for homeless and foster youth to access housing resources during academic terms and breaks, regardless of student housing availability. A homeless youth, defined as a student under 25 verified as homeless within the past 24 months, can access housing resources at California Community Colleges. A homeless youth, under 25 and verified as homeless within the past 24 months, can access housing resources at California Community Colleges. Eligibility includes a homeless services provider, TRIO program director, or financial aid administrator. Former homeless youth status is retained for six years from admission. Section 90001.5 of the Education Code is amended. Each campus of the California State University must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing. Priority is given to those needing year-round housing. Priority for student housing at California State University campuses is given to current and former homeless youth and foster youth, with a focus on year-round accommodation. Additionally, housing during academic breaks is provided at no extra cost. Each California State University campus is asked to create a plan to ensure housing resources are available for current and former homeless and foster youth during academic breaks, regardless of campus housing availability. A "homeless youth" under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months, can be admitted to a California State University campus. Verification can be done by a homeless services provider. A homeless youth under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months, can be admitted to a California State University campus. Verification can be done by a homeless services provider, the director of a federal TRIO program, or a financial aid administrator. The student retains their status as a former homeless youth for six years from the date of admission. Section 92660 of the Education Code is amended. Each campus of the University of California with student housing facilities must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing. Priority is given for year-round residence in housing facilities open during school breaks. The University of California prioritizes current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing in their student housing facilities, offering year-round residence during academic breaks at no extra cost. Priority is given to those eligible for housing open for occupation for the most days in the calendar year. The University of California prioritizes housing for current and former homeless youth and foster youth, offering year-round residence during academic breaks at no extra cost. Another campus of the University is requested to develop a plan to ensure housing resources for these students during academic terms and breaks, regardless of student housing facilities. A "homeless youth" under 25 years old, verified as homeless within the past 24 months, can receive housing priority at the University of California. Verification can be done by a homeless services provider. The section defines who qualifies as a homeless services provider, director of specific programs, and financial aid administrator. It also states that a student verified as a former homeless youth retains that status for six years. The University of California is exempt unless the Regents make it applicable.
